chatgpt_double_star.new_statement: Any reform should keep a meaningful state role in presidential elections while reducing the gap between the national vote and the outcome so more voters feel represented. A practical compromise is to curb winner-take-all by encouraging proportional allocation (or a uniform, non‑gerrymandered district method with statewide backstop rules), while also binding electors to certified results and strengthening safeguards against manipulation. If a national popular‑vote compact is pursued, it should include shared minimum standards for ballot access, paper-based verification, audits, and clear recount triggers, with changes phased in so voters and states can adapt and confidence can grow.

chatgpt_double_star_rankings.new_statement: Preserve a state-based Electoral College framework while making outcomes better reflect the national will by phasing out strict winner-take-all in favor of proportional or district-based allocation of electors, with electors bound to certified results. Any shift toward a national popular-vote compact should be conditioned on uniform baseline rules for ballot access, paper-auditable tabulation, routine audits, and clear recount triggers so results are trusted across states. States should also be free to adopt ranked-choice ballots for president to ensure the winner earns broad support and to reduce the incentive to campaign only in a few swing areas.

chatgpt_double_star_personas.new_statement: Reform should keep the Electoral College’s state-based role so smaller and rural communities are not sidelined, while reducing winner-take-all distortions so more voters feel their ballot matters wherever they live. A practical compromise is to allow or encourage proportional (or clearly drawn district-based) allocation of electors, bind electors to certified results, and adopt nationwide baseline rules for voter access, hand-auditable paper ballots, routine audits, and clear recount triggers. States that want to move further could join a national popular-vote compact only after those safeguards are in place and with transparent, bipartisan oversight to protect confidence in close outcomes.
